But there was something in that marriage of theatrical Gothic and this new thing called novels that let a reader see into the dark spaces of a man's mind. Something that wouldn't die. Something that was both ancient as the hills and fresh as morning dew.

The old ways of chivalry run deep in these Gothic tales like roots in hard ground. In Walpole's castle story you can see how he took them old knight's codes and twisted em new. Them writers, Walpole particular, they saw something missing in their own time. Something noble that had gone out of the world. They looked back at them knights with their honor and their bravery like men dying of thirst might look at water. Made it all shine prettier than it ever was, truth be told. Romantic-like.

Walpole, he was deep in the muck of politics when he wrote his tale. Seen things that made him doubt mankind's goodness. Maybe he reckoned that old Gothic times held something pure that had leaked out of the world drop by drop, leaving nothing but dry dust behind. You can see it clear as day in how he writes Frederic. Before you even meet the man you know him by the marks of chivalry he bears like old scars. A prince who's suffered and been changed by it. Said to have fallen to infidels in some far land. The whole thing drawn larger than life like a shadow at sunset, all excess and darkness stretching long across the ground.

The chain moves like a great serpent through the world. From raw earth to the hands of them that would possess it. It was invented by a man named Oliver in a time when such things still had names and still meant something to those that spoke them. He wrote it down. The planning. The doing. The watching. All of it writ in ledgers now lost to time.

Six pillars hold it up. Production and supply. Inventory. Location. The moving of things. And last the knowing of things. These are the bones of it. The skeleton on which hangs all commerce in the world.

First comes the making. Without the making there aint nothing else to follow. Manager men with clipboards and tired eyes study the wanting of people. What they'll buy. What they'll trade their hours for. They watch the market like old seers reading entrails, trying to divine what will come. Where to build. How many to build. Which plants will birth which things. It's all numbers to them. Cold arithmetic of profit and loss.

He'd seen it himself. In the stores where the fluorescent lights hummed like living things. Walmart. Target. Each with its own bible of rules. How to dress. How to move. How to stack the boxes when they came off the trucks in the dark hours. Everything written down like scripture. Without these words there was only chaos.

Then comes supply. The choices of what can be done here and what must be sent away. Managers moving pieces on a board like generals in some bloodless war. Some work stays. Some work goes to distant places where hands are cheaper and the machines never sleep. They call it velocity. A word that means the speed of money moving through the world. But it aint really about speed. It's about the hunger. The endless hunger of the market that must be fed.

The whole thing moves like some great machine. Pieces interlocked. Gears turning gears. And at the center of it all sits man with his ledgers and his wants. Trying to make order of a world that don't want ordering.

They wrote of parlors and teacups in them days but two books stood apart like dark prophets in the wastes. Oliver Twist and Wuthering Heights. Books that carried in them something older and more terrible than the mannered society they was meant to chronicle. Something that spoke of mystery and madness both.

The boy Oliver dreamt dark dreams in his fever and they was dreams what showed the truth of things. Truth about what he was and what had been done to him by men with no souls. He lay there in his blood watching Sikes and Crackit argue like specters in the dark. Their voices carried to him across some terrible divide between what was real and what wasnt. Then the gunshot came again like it always did. Always would. Sound of it echoing off the walls of his skull while lights danced before him like corpsefire. Someone carried him away but he didnt know who. Might have been the devil himself. Pain followed him through it all like some dark companion that wouldnt leave him be.

Time itself went strange in them books. Day wasnt day no more and night wasnt night. Hours stretched out like tar then snapped back quick as a whip. Silence came down heavy as a shroud then broke apart into madness. Time itself had gone wrong in a world where such things could happen to children. Where evil men could work their will on the innocent and God just watched from his high place, saying nothing.

The boy had no power over any of it. No more than a leaf has power over the wind. Forces bigger than him was at work and they was dark forces indeed. Old Fagin had started to break him like you'd break a wild horse. Teaching him that resistance was pointless in a world gone wrong. Teaching him that hope was for fools. The boy was learning his lessons well. Too well maybe. Learning to accept the darkness rather than fight it. Learning to let the world have its way with him cause fighting only brought more pain.

He'd worked with the children in them days after school let out. Teaching them what he could though his knowledge ran mostly to letters and words and such. One of them teachers had come to him about a boy. Adrian was his name. Third grade maybe fourth. The boy couldn't read and there was something peculiar in the way of it. Some letters the boy knew true as truth itself but others might as well have been ciphers writ in ash for all he could make of them. The boy was Mexican or something like it though he spoke English pure as spring water.

They worked at it for days until the boy's mother came. She'd walked in while he watched the stragglers, them other children being gone on some venture elsewhere. The woman spoke no English. None. He tried what Spanish he knew which wasnt much, scraping together words like a man gathering kindling in the dark. Then the truth of it came to him like revelation. The boy could read right enough. Just not in English. The letters themselves was what confounded him.

He tells this tale now because of what it means. Here in California where languages mix like waters at a confluence. Sometimes the troubles aint what you'd think. Even a child speaking English pure as mountain air might founder in the reading of it. Everyone knows this truth but what's to be done? For Adrian the path was clear enough. Teach him them letters. Teach him the sounds. But for them children who barely know English at all the answer aint so simple. No single solution would suffice. Not them two-language schools nor full immersion nor private teaching nor special classes. The answer lay in all of these things together like threads in a rope.

Them two-language schools aint just for Spanish speakers neither. Studies show all children do better in such places though folk fear it like they fear what they don't understand. Fear it's a waste. But that aint true. If we was to make this common practice instead of rare exception every child would profit from it. Don't need every teacher speaking two tongues neither. That'd be asking too much. But there aint no reason we can't have helpers who do. People who understand both worlds. People who can bridge that divide like a rope bridge over troubled waters.

From when we're young they tell us of something greater than ourselves. Something vast and unknowable that stretches beyond the thin veil of understanding. Some find it in wooden pews on Sunday mornings, others in ancient temples or deep within the chambers of their own hearts. Most take what their fathers gave them like hand-me-down coats, worn and familiar. Others cast it all away, declaring themselves alone in the dark cosmos of their own making. We trade one truth for another like copper pennies, each gleaming briefly before turning green in our palms. All of us searching. All of us reaching through the black for some pale light to guide us home.

The rain came down hard on the tin roof that evening, drumming like bullets on metal. Me and my father sat watching it fall, cigarette smoke rising between us like ghost breath in the humid air. Cardinal, he said when I asked about the birds. Just that. Cardinal. The water poured from the gutters, drowning the flowers my mother had planted years before. He was getting smaller, my father. His clothes hung on him like rags on a scarecrow, his hair thin as corn silk. His eyes fixed on something out there in the rain, something I couldn't see. Maybe he couldn't either. I wanted to tell him how the world would empty when he left it but the words stuck like thorns in my throat. Instead I moved closer, our shoulders almost touching, and we watched the rain fall together in the dying June light.

He went in December. Five days after I turned twenty-two. The doctors had pumped him full of poison to buy time but time was a poor bargain when paid for in pain. I lay in my bed those nights cursing whatever God might be listening. But no God was. No God had been for a long time.

I didn't watch him go. Couldn't. The man who made me was unmaking himself and I couldn't bear to see it. Better to remember him whole than watch him fragment piece by piece. I knew him better than any of them did. Knew he wouldn't want his boy there at the end. So I curled up like a child in my bed and waited three days for news that never came. No one called. No one spoke his name. Like he'd been erased from the world with no mark left behind.

He rode out across the tobacco fields in the morning light, John Taylor of Caroline, an early Republican and a man who knew the land. The fields stretched endless before him and he knew that from this earth sprang all truths about governance and freedom that any man might need to know. The land was his teacher and his guide both.

In those days the nation was young and raw and unspoiled by old world thinking. Taylor saw in this virgin territory a chance to build something pure and true, unmarked by the rotted traditions of Europe. He believed in the rights of men, not as separate things to be parceled out but as one beating heart that if wounded in any part would sicken and die entire. These rights, he reckoned, must stand beyond the reach of any government's grasping hands.

He knew the darkness in men's hearts. Knew it like he knew the taste of dirt on his tongue after a dry spell. The strong would prey upon the weak if left unchecked, this was the way of beasts but not of men in society. Taylor held to a stark view of good and evil, like day and night with no twilight between them. All virtue and vice in government, he said, must flow from human nature itself.

Good principles were simple things: protect what a man owns, nurture the soil that feeds him, ward against the money-changers who'd bleed the land dry. He believed that even corrupt men, if bound by righteous principles, might still serve the common good. Self-interest drove all men, this he knew, but it turned poisonous only when it led men to build private kingdoms on the backs of others.

The Constitution to Taylor was like a fence line - clear and fixed and not to be moved. He wanted the Federal government bound tight within those borders, given no more rope than explicitly granted. A powerful central authority was a hungry beast that needed constant feeding, and in the feeding would grow tyrannical. But mere words on paper weren't enough - you had to know the mind of the men who'd written them. The Declaration, that was the true charter in Taylor's mind, marking the states as sovereign entities and not one mass to be ruled from above.

He watched the sun climb higher over his fields, knowing that in the earth beneath his feet lay all the wisdom any republic would ever need. The morning light caught the dew like a thousand small fires in the grass, and somewhere a crow called out across the silence.

He stood there staring down into that porcelain void, mind working like some cold machine that knew only to observe and record but never to feel. Thoughts came and went like ghosts in the night, there and gone before they could take hold. His consciousness moved like water over stone, smooth and purposeless and pure.

He remembered a book once. Drawing on the Right Side of the Brain it was called, given to him by some artist he'd known in that other life. Six years old when the urge to draw first came upon him, that hunger never leaving. Book taught everything from holding lead to seeing what was there instead of what the mind said ought to be there. Taught about frames too. How to section off the world into pieces small enough for a man to grasp. Turn something vast like a kitchen with its fruit and tables and doorways into something simple. Just shapes on a plane.

Standing there now though he couldn't find that frame in his mind. Too vast what lay before him. Too awful in its simple presence. Picasso had his blues and Monet his greens and those Italian masters had all the colors God gave the world. But this. This was brown. Deep and profound as creation itself. His artistic awakening come to him in a public toilet at Rite Aid.

His fingers found the lever. Muscles tensed and relaxed like some ancient machinery. Water moved in its eternal circles, clear as winter air. Matter broke free and scattered to nothing. Second time he hit it harder. Anxious. Desperate maybe. But that brown mass clung there like some primitive life form. Refusing the water's call.

He stood with his mop like a soldier with his rifle. Feet spread. Green tie cinched at his throat like a noose. Staring down at what some nameless patron had left behind. Message written in the language of digested meat and vegetation. He pulled at the paper roll, wrapped his hand like a man preparing for war until it was thick as a winter glove. Bent at the waist slow and deliberate. Hand descending into that white bowl like his mama reaching into the oven on Thanksgiving day.

They die behind the wheel. Young ones. Not yet grown. The statistics tell their tale in cold numbers writ in blood upon the asphalt like some ancient curse laid down by gods who care nothing for the living or the dead.

The men in white coats at the Institute speak of brains not ready. Not finished. As if some carpenter had left his work half done and gone. But there was more to it than that. The rawness of youth. The not knowing. These things conspired to roll their vehicles like worthless dice across the highways of America. To press pedals too deep. To drift from the hardpan into darkness.

He'd seen them. Packs of them. Moving in their metal coffins with the windows down and the music loud enough to wake whatever dead thing might still care to listen. The California men with their charts and their studies showed what any fool already knew. More bodies in the car meant more bodies in the ground.

Some states tried. Made rules about when they could drive and who could ride beside them. But these were weak medicine. Like trying to stop a bullet with tissue paper. The truth was stark and cold as November dawn. They weren't ready. None of them. Even at eighteen the blood ran too hot, too wild. Zuckerman knew. He'd studied them. Watched how they craved the rush of speed like addicts craving the needle. The pure animal thrill of it.

And more were coming. Children of the boom times growing up and reaching for keys like they were reaching for freedom itself. By 2010 they'd flood the roads like water after rain. Unless.

The answer was simple as a blade. Keep them from the wheel till eighteen. Let them learn in school yards and parking lots with teachers watching close. Make them practice with their elders like apprentice smiths learning the ways of iron and fire. Six hours behind the wheel and fifty more beside someone who knew the road's cruel ways. Make it the same in every state from sea to sea. One law. One rule. One way to keep the young blood in their veins instead of on the road.

It wasn't new thinking. Wasn't revolutionary. But maybe it would keep more of them breathing. Maybe it would give them time to grow into whatever they might become instead of ending as broken things in ditches waiting for the coroner to come and write their final chapter in his leather book of endings.

They called it Central Auditory Processing Disorder though that wasnt what it was at first. Back in the old days, the 1950s, they named it auditory imperception like some ancient malady that crawled up from the depths of medical tomes long forgotten. The disorder lived in the brain, in the tangled mess of neural pathways where sound goes to die or be reborn as meaning. These afflicted souls could hear right enough but the sound came wrong somehow. Like echoes in a canyon that never quite reach the other side.

The Italians came first. Bocca and his lot. Testing children whose minds couldn't parse the world's cacophony. Then Kimura with his dichotic trials, splitting sounds between ears like a man trying to ford two rivers at once. The disorder showed itself in ways that defied simple telling. Some couldn't track a sound through space, like a hunter who's lost his quarry's trail. Others couldn't sort one sound from another when they came fast and thick like raindrops in a storm. Words fell dead and meaningless, stripped of the subtle changes that make mockery different from truth.

To find it they had to look deep. Audiologists and speech doctors and mind-readers all, watching and testing and measuring with their instruments and questionnaires, trying to map the territory of a broken soundscape. They'd sit a child down and pour sounds into their ears, numbers and words falling like stones into still water, watching for ripples that came wrong or didn't come at all. Sometimes they'd thread wires into the ear itself, listening for the ghost-signals of the brain's response, like trying to read the future in the entrails of birds.

No test stood alone as truth. No single path led to understanding. The disorder remained elusive as smoke, its causes unknown as the thoughts of dead men. They could only watch and measure and catalogue the ways it manifested, like tracking an invisible beast by the marks it left behind.

The boy sat on her couch and there was fear in him. Sixteen years and already the world had worked its dark upon him. I knew then what I must do. What I had always known but hadnt seen clear till that moment. The path ahead through the dark trees of human suffering like a road marked in ash.

They were there at the house, the law. Blue lights washing the walls in cold pulses. I told them what I knew from my learning of minds at the college, words written in books that seemed pale now against the thing itself. They beckoned me speak to the parents, these keepers of the boy's darkness. Their words came like smoke, twisting, formless. Simple disputes, they said. Manipulation, they said. But their eyes betrayed them. Truth is a thing that cannot be buried no matter how deep you dig.

I had seen others before. Young ones mostly. Running from what ate at them inside. Some found the bottle, some the needle. Some just ran and kept running. But that boy on the couch, he stayed with me. Like a marker in the waste showing which way led to salvation.

Years before I had walked different paths. Hair bright as toxic flowers. Metal in my flesh like badges of defiance. Standing with the ones society marked different. Gay. Straight. Everything between. We were all of us pilgrims in the same dark land. I fought their battles because they were mine too. Justice aint a thing you can hold in your hand but its real as blood.

The work called to me then like it calls now. To wade into the darkness where children huddle from monsters wearing parent faces. To carry what light I could. Service. Respect. The old words. True words. They beat in me like a second heart.

This is what I know: Every soul is a universe entire. We lose one, we lose a world. This is the work. To save what worlds we can. Even if we save just one, it matters. It matters more than anything else there is.

He set the papers down and studied them in the dim light. Words about sleep and wakefulness and the dark chambers of the mind where men go to rest. The biological and the sociocultural, he thought. As if such things could be separated like water from oil. As if the mind wasn't already a battlefield of inherited demons and the ghosts of our fathers' sins.

In the deep folds of the brain where sleep comes calling there are neurons firing like distant stars in the hypothalamus. Orexin they called it. As if naming a thing gave you power over it. The mice they used lay sleeping in their cages while men in white coats watched and waited and recorded. GABAB receptors switching on and off like traffic signals in an abandoned city. The agonist baclofen increasing sleep time like some mechanical god deciding when creatures should wake and when they should dream.

He thought about inheritance. About what passes from father to son besides blood and bone. About the sleepless nights that plague whole families like some biblical curse. The sociocultural they called it. As if you could separate a man's sleep from his life, from his work, from the grinding poverty or the soft beds of privilege. As if sleep wasn't already political.

Primary disorders they named them. Dyssomnias and Parasomnias like ancient diseases. Insomnia. Hypersomnia. Narcolepsy. Words that tried to catch the darkness between sleeping and waking. That tried to name the terror of lying awake while the world slept or of falling into dreams while the world demanded wakefulness. They had categories and subcategories, axes and specifications, trying to order the chaos of human sleep like sorting grains of sand.

The mice slept while the scientists watched. The neurons fired or didn't fire. But somewhere in the dark a man lay awake counting his breaths, counting the hours until dawn, carrying in his cells some inherited glitch that kept sleep at bay like a sentry standing guard against the night.

Been here at University Park going on three years now. The getting around weighs heavy. That first year they put me in East Halls, far out on the edge of things where the wind comes raw across the athletic fields and the stadium stands like some colosseum against the gray Pennsylvania sky. Walking west toward classes was a pilgrimage of sorts. Twenty-five minutes through whatever weather God or the devil saw fit to cast down. Snow or rain or that peculiar State College cold that cuts through wool and cotton alike.

Talked to someone who'd walked these paths before. Not much older but he spoke of times when East Halls stood alone out there, nothing but empty land between the dorms and civilization. Now theres buildings. The Creamery. Health Services. Apartments sprung up like weeds in abandoned lots. The campus spreads like some living thing, consuming ground, making the distances longer. Making the walking harder.

The bicycle stands as testament to what might be. Simple machine. Steel and rubber and chain. But it aint enough to have the machines. Need people to ride them. Need paths for them to ride upon.

Friend of mine took up riding again after years without. Said he couldnt reckon why he ever stopped. Said it wasnt cool for a time but now its the only way. The most efficient too. Bowl of oatmeal will carry you thirty miles if youre willing to work for it. I live off campus now, far as any dorm. Bought myself a bike. Best decision I made. Thomas building sits twenty-five minutes walking distance from my door. On the bike I can make it in five if I push hard enough. But Pollock Road lies between, straight as an arrow but treacherous in its own way. Walking has its merits but time aint one of them. Too busy for walking these days. Without the bike Id lose thirty minutes, forty maybe, each day just getting to Thomas. Adds up to more than two hours every week. Time I dont have to give.

The paths I take each day are written in time and distance. Each step measured against the clock. Each pedal stroke bringing me closer to where I need to be. The campus grows and changes like some restless beast, but the bicycle remains constant. Simple. True.

He sat there in the dim light reading the old book about the world that was. The pages yellow and worn, speaking of things that aint no more and maybe never were. A world of machines and money and men who thought themselves gods. He thought about how they'd made their own hell and called it paradise.

In this book there was a man called Huxley who saw it coming like a storm on the horizon. Dark and terrible. Writing about people trapped in glass towers and concrete caves, all of them thinking they was free but wearing chains they couldn't even see. Each one of them born into their place like cattle in their pens, marked and branded before they could walk. The high ones and the low ones all the same, just different colors of the same dead flesh.

They had ways of making people think what they wanted them to think. Words whispered in the dark while they slept. Poison in their minds like the oil that used to run in the ground. Making them want things. Making them need things. Making them forget they ever wanted anything else.

He thought about how there wasn't no real love in that world. No true feeling between a man and a woman. Just bodies moving against bodies in the dark, mechanical-like, same as the machines they worshipped. The people in the story, they wasn't really people at all. More like shadows cast on a wall, all of them the same shape, none of them casting their own light.

The high ones, they knew what they was doing. Keeping everybody in their place with sweet lies and softer chains than iron. Making the low ones think they was happy being low, making the middle ones think they was better than the low ones, making everybody think they was right where they ought to be. Like a spider in the center of its web, watching everything move just the way it wanted.

He closed the book and sat there in the darkness thinking about how sometimes a man can see the truth better looking back than those who lived it looking forward. How sometimes the end of things is written in their beginning, if only you know how to read the signs.

Four years back I sat in a classroom learning of Islam. The question that burned in every mind was whether their faith carried violence in its heart. Even now the question hangs like smoke in dead air. Since the towers fell I watched how the papers and screens shifted from raw hatred to something worse. A kind of hollow acceptance. Like a wound gone dead. Strange days these are when a man called Barack Obama whose blood carries the old prayers of Islam could stand for president. Strange days indeed.

The Prophet's story gnaws at me. What they write of him and what was done stand apart like two strangers eyeing each other across a fire. I knew him as a warrior who brought the sword first and the word after. Who made men bow or bleed. But in these pages he walks humble and pure as morning light. They paint him martyr-like, misunderstood, while men came crawling to his truth like moths to flame.

And there's something else. Something that makes the blood run cold. They write of him doing things that echo the Christ. Taking meat and milk and making it feed forty when it should've fed four. It's a kind of theft, writing him this way. As if they could steal the holy light from one and pin it to another. Makes me think of a man wearing another's skin.

The stories they tell come wrapped in layers of telling. This man heard from that man who heard from another until the truth gets lost in the telling. Like tracking footprints in windblown sand. They mean these tellings to be proof but they read like whispers in the dark.

What eats at me most is how they've made him gentle. Made him wise and soft-spoken when history shows his hands were red. I wonder if those who bow toward Mecca know the true face of their prophet. If they know how he really came to power. But maybe some lies are easier to swallow than truth.

The teachings lay scattered like leaves across time, blown far from where they first fell. The words of the man called Jesus, pure and unadorned in their time, had been carried off like ash in a storm, replaced by doctrines strange and foreign to what he'd known. He'd spoken his truth and they'd buried it deep, layer upon layer, year upon year, until what remained bore little likeness to its origin.

Yet something stirred in the darkness of these latter days. A awakening like the first gray light before dawn. The old guard stood fast against it, clutching their inherited truths like talismans against the gathering storm, but their numbers grew thin, their voices weak against the rising wind of change.

Among the believers a hunger grew, raw and desperate, to strip away the accumulated years, to peel back the layers until nothing remained but the bare bones of what that man had meant when he'd walked the dusty roads of Galilee. It would take time, perhaps generations, but the tide had turned. There was no stopping it now.

They would dismantle it all, piece by piece, doctrine by doctrine, like taking apart an ancient machine whose purpose had been forgotten. Back through time they would go, through centuries of accumulated belief, until they stood where he had stood, saw what he had seen. The great institutions would remain, but transformed, stripped of their ornaments, their complex theologies reduced to essential truths.

The scattered branches would draw together again, like tributaries flowing back to their source. Unity would replace division, simplicity would conquer complexity. It had happened before - empires had fallen and risen again transformed, slaves had become masters, the persecuted had become rulers.

Before all this, before the man called Jesus walked the earth, there had been only the faith of Abraham. The Romans had come to Jerusalem in the sixty-third year before his birth, finding a people already divided - Sadducees in their temples, Pharisees in their houses of learning, Essenes in their desert retreats, Zealots with their hidden daggers, and the common folk caught between them all like chaff in the wind.

The greed of men lay bare in them pages like some ancient truth writ in blood and bone. Aint no man ever looked down from his height to them below except to count the shapes of their backs bent in toil. The Jungle showed this plain as day and plainer still.

You could see it most in them factory men. The owners. The bosses. They was like carrion birds circling some dying thing, watching and waiting. All they wanted was to build higher walls and bigger machines and damn whatever lay in their path. Sinclair he wrote it true when he said them buildings stood blacklike against the sky, them chimneys belching smoke that stretched on forever like some kind of evil prayer. That smoke carried death in it but they didnt care none. The waste and the filth from them animal pens just ran wherever it would, like blood from some great wound in the earth.

Them workers was worth less than the dirt they stood on. "From top to bottom just hatred and jealousy," Sinclair wrote, "and a man aint worth nothing against a dollar." They'd work a man till he was used up then throw him away like a spent shell casing. No warning. No help. Just out into the cold world broken and empty. Wasnt no law to protect nobody back then. The bosses they just drove them workers harder and harder like they was trying to see how much suffering a human soul could take before it broke.

The people living there in Packingtown they was expected to endure it all like it was some kind of natural law. Like gravity or death. Wasnt no help coming. The unions that formed was just another kind of vulture picking at their bones. Sinclair he called them slaves and that's what they was. "Foreign people," he wrote, "hanging on by their fingernails and living or dying by the whims of men no better than slave drivers." And under them conditions sin and corruption grew like weeds in untended soil. That's just the way of things when men's souls get crushed under the weight of other men's greed.

The words lay scattered like bones bleached white in desert suns. Dreamland. Poe had called it among his better works and perhaps it was. There in the margins of old worlds where Thulé dwelt, that word torn from Virgil's ancient pages speaking of lands beyond the edge where nothing lived and nothing died. The Greeks knew it. Called it the end of all things known. But there were other voices calling through time's dark corridors.

The German writers had caught Poe's eye and mind both. Their words like black rivers flowing through his consciousness. Gothe among them. Karl Arndt saw it clear as morning, wrote it down in his own book about Poe and Gothe's words dancing together like lovers or perhaps like mourners at the same dark wake.

Oxford speaks of Gothe and his Faust, that tale told twice over. First in 1808 and again as death came calling in 1832. Within those pages lay the King of Thulé, broken and lost. His queen dead and cold, leaving nothing but a goblet and memories that burned like poison. The king drank deep and wept deeper still until the darkness took him. Gave away his kingdom like fallen leaves in autumn wind, kept only that cursed cup. Walked to the edge of all things and cast it down into black waters before following it into the void. Mirror dark and terrible of Poe's own demons, the bottle that called him ever downward.

Thulé echoes twice in Poe's writings. Once in Pit and Pendulum's horror and twice more in Dreamland like dark bookends holding nightmare pages. These tales speak to one another across the void, Gothe's king and Poe's wanderer both. The speaker walks through shadows where color dies and ghosts of dead friends whisper on cold winds. Same darkness that swallowed Thulé's king whole when his queen's death emptied his world of light.

Gothe's shadow stretched long across those times. Poe knew him, had to know him, if only through Tennyson's reflected light. The old tales kept being born again in new forms, like dark phoenixes rising from their own ashes. Each telling carrying something of the original's terrible truth.

The law spoke of malice and rights and consequences but the store manager knew none of these things. He sat in his office that evening while the applesauce lay spilled and glistening on the cold tile floor like some pale viscera of commerce. The fluorescent lights hummed overhead casting their sickly pallor upon all things below.

First came Wayne with his news of the spill. Then Haddigan. The manager looked at them with dead eyes while steam rose from his microwave dinner. Didnt have time for customer complaints he said. He knew of the others who had fallen. Five souls gone down on these same floors in months past. Their bodies sprawled and broken like casualties of some retail war. But he ate his dinner all the same.

The woman Palmer came through at half past five that evening. She didnt see the applesauce there waiting. Silent. Patient. Malevolent in its slickness. Her feet went out from under her like judgment had been passed and she lay broken on the floor while overhead the fluorescent lights kept their merciless vigil.

The law spoke of obligations not born of contract. Of conduct despicable and willful and conscious. The courts had seen such things before. Had named them and catalogued them in their endless repositories of human failings. Taylor versus Superior Court spoke of dangerous consequences known but not avoided. Of rights discarded like so much waste.

The manager knew these things or should have known them. The five who fell before Palmer were harbingers he chose to ignore. Their falls echoing through the store's history like ghostly footfalls. Now Palmer sought her due in compensatory damages and punitive both. The law would not look away. Not from this. Not from the cold calculation of a man who chose his dinner over the safety of others. The motion for summary judgment would fail. Of this there could be no doubt.

The wanting came at fourteen. A hollowness that wouldnt be filled. Three years gone and still it gnawed, a darkness in her bones telling her it wasnt things she needed but someone. Boys came and went like pale ghosts through the halls of her days, their awkward advances falling away into nothing. She studied herself in the depths of night, asking questions that had no answers, watching theories rise and fall like dead leaves in autumn wind.

The house was quiet most days. Her parents moved through rooms like spirits, their voices soft as ash falling. No shouting. No storm of words between them save the few times she'd rise up wild and free against their quietude. She was their opposite, full of fire and light, drawing others to her like moths to flame.

But this day was different. This day carried blood in its teeth. A scream cut through the morning silence, her mothers voice turned brutal and strange. She found the woman sprawled on the kitchen floor, pain written across her face like an ancient text. Mama what is it, she said. But she knew. The stepping stool lay toppled, the high cabinet door swung wide like a broken wing. Her mother's words came ragged and torn. Hospital, she said. Take me.

The girl gathered her mother up like something precious and broken. The strength in her arms, hard won in classes she'd taken, served her now as scripture serves the faithful. She carried her burden through halls that smelled of death and disinfectant, calling out in a voice that brought white-coated figures running. They took her mother away on a rolling bed, metal wheels clicking against tile like rosary beads, and left the girl alone with her thoughts in the waiting room where hope went to die.

A vase, she thought. All this for a vase in a high cabinet. The world could turn cruel on such small things.

They studied them women for twenty years. Watched what they ate and how they lived. Mediterranean folk eating their olives and fish and grain. No potatoes. The nurses filling out their forms year after year marking down what passed their lips like some desperate accounting of sustenance in a world gone lean. Seventy four thousand of them. More. All of them marking time with their pencils. Each morsel each crumb written down in columns neat as grave markers.

The old ways. The ways of the Mediterranean people. Oil from olives not butter. Fish not beef. Wine in moderation like penitents at communion. The nurses didnt know it then but their forms their little boxes checked or unchecked would tell a story of life and death. Some would live. Some would die. The numbers dont lie.

They watched them all through the years. The ones who ate like the Mediterranean people and the ones who didnt. Death came visiting as it always does. Heart attacks. Strokes. The researchers counting the dead like battlefield clerks. Two thousand heart attacks. Near two thousand strokes. More than a thousand dead from their hearts or their minds giving way.

But there was something in the numbers. Something in the counting. The women who ate like they did in the old country, they lived. More of them anyway. The ones who scored highest on their Mediterranean ways had less chances of their hearts failing or their minds bleeding out. Point seven one they called it in their statistics. Numbers that meant life or death.

They adjusted for everything. Smoking. Exercise. The pills they took. Whether they still bled with the moon. But still the numbers held true. Like some ancient wisdom passed down through generations of olive growers and fishermen. The old ways. The ways that kept death at bay just a little longer.

These numbers they found, these calculations, they were more than just figures on paper. They were a map showing the way back to something older. Something that worked. In their scientific papers they called it significant. But what they meant was that some old truths still hold. That sometimes the old ways are the right ways. Even if we need numbers now to prove what our ancestors knew in their bones.

The sign said Hitler lives in Burma and the girl held it above her head like some dark portent, standing there on the corner in the gunmetal light of morning. She'd been in pictures. Movies about pregnant children and roller skating girls. Now she stood sentinel against the gathering dark.

Burma. Myanmar they called it now. A land of temples and bones where men in olive drab had taken what wasnt theirs to take. Theyd come in the night with their rifles and their machineguns and when the sun rose there were new masters of that ancient place. The monks came after. Men in saffron robes like flames moving through the streets, their bare feet marking paths in dust that would soon turn red. They permitted it at first. Then they didnt.

The dead dont keep their own count. A Japanese man with a camera died there. Kenji Nagai. He lay in the street and bled into the dust while the soldiers walked past him like he was nothing at all. They said thirteen dead but a colonel who'd run told different. Thousands, he said. Thousands.

It was an old story. Old as time. Men with power and men who wanted it and men who died in between. Roman emperors who thought themselves gods. Japanese kings who were gods. The president talking to preachers on the telephone like God himself was on the party line.

In China they killed them in a square. Students and workers and thinkers. The government said three hundred. The Red Cross said thousands. In Rwanda they killed with machetes, Hutus and Tutsis playing out ancient hatreds in blood. And there was Hitler. Always Hitler. The camps and the chambers and the ash. The ash that fell like gray snow. The ash that was people once. That was children once.

These things dont change. They wear different faces but the story stays the same. Power and blood. Blood and power. The weak and the strong. The dead and the living. And sometimes a girl with a sign standing on a corner telling tales that might be true.

He sat at that piano like a man possessed by spirits of the old world, Duke they called him and Duke he was, ruling over that kingdom of brass and wood and string with hands that knew every shade of sound a man could conjure. The keys beneath his fingers whispered secrets that only he could hear. His orchestra was his voice and his voice was the sound of america itself, raw and beautiful and terrible all at once.

They say he wrote for men like they was instruments themselves and wrote for instruments like they was men breathing their last breath. Each player carried within him some divine spark that the Duke could see clear as day, could write into the very marrow of the music itself. The way he done it weren't like other men. He'd craft these pieces like a man building a house of cards in a thunderstorm, each part balanced just so, leaving space for them that needed to speak their piece when the spirit moved them.

That Creole Love Call, now that was something else entirely. Voice rising up out of nowhere like smoke from a dying fire, twelve bars repeating like the stations of some heathen cross. First the voice comes pure as spring water then turns rough like whiskey burning down your throat. Then that muted trumpet wailing like a lost soul in the night, followed by clarinet high and lonesome while the piano speaks in tongues underneath it all. The whole band takes up the cry then, brass and reed fighting like cats and dogs till finally that voice comes back growling like some creature that ain't got no name.

Hot and Bothered was different. Miley with his trumpet crying out and Baby Cox answering back with sounds no human throat should make, like two old prophets arguing about the end of days. And when they played It Don't Mean a Thing, old Tricky Sam Nanton would pull sounds from that trombone that'd make the devil himself sit up and take notice.

That's what the Duke done. He took all them separate voices, human and brass and wood alike, and he made them speak in tongues that wasn't ever heard before nor since. Each note carrying the weight of all them years of american music in it, each phrase telling stories that wasn't never wrote down in no book.

They came to study the shells in the winter of that year. The boy watched as his father held the ancient spiraled thing up to the light. Turning it this way and that like some old priest studying auguries in bone. The shell white as chalk against the gray of his palm. Its whorls clean and mathematical in their perfection. Like God himself had drawn them with compass and rule.

The father knew things about such matters. Had studied the geometries of life and death in the cold halls of universities now long abandoned. He spoke of organisms and their changes, of constraints that bound them like prison walls. Of numbers that could capture the very essence of their being.

They laid the shells out on a wooden table scarred with age. X-ray images scattered like pale ghosts. The computer hummed its electric drone in the corner, running programs that could build shells from numbers alone. CerioShell they called it, though such names meant little now.

The boy watched as his father traced the whorl patterns with a fingertip. Each shell a testament to time's slow turning. The columella running through them like a spine, the sutures marking each year's growth like rings in a tree. The aperture where once life had crawled forth into light, now empty as a dead man's socket.

You can read the life of a thing in its shell, the father said. Each whorl tells its story. Like chapters in some ancient book written in the language of calcium and time. The boy nodded though he didn't fully understand. He picked up one of the smaller shells, held it to his ear like he'd seen in pictures. Listened for the sound of some long-dead sea.

They worked through the gray afternoons, measuring, calculating, trying to understand the mathematics of creation. The father spoke of Thompson and Raup and others who'd tried to capture life's geometry in numbers. The boy drew lines on paper, counted whorls, recorded measurements in columns neat as grave markers.

In the end they had their data. Cold numbers that spoke of how things grew and changed across the vast wastes of time. The father fed them into the machine and watched as it spun out its digital shells, perfect as prayers. But he knew in his heart that no equation could fully capture the mystery of how life wrote itself in calcium and pearl.

Some things, he thought, watching his son sleep that night, lay beyond the reach of numbers. Like the love between father and son. Like the mystery of time itself, spiraling ever outward like the whorls of an infinite shell.

He studied the numbers laid before him, cold and unmoving like dead things in the Indonesian sun. Ten years and the children kept dying same as they always had. Same as their mothers. The government men spoke of goals and targets and millennium dreams but the truth was written in blood and afterbirth on dirt floors where women lay dying.

They'd put trained folk at the births now, seven births in ten had someone who knew the old ways. Midwives mostly, their hands dark with tradition but empty of the steel tools that might save a hemorrhaging mother. The numbers lied. They always did. Down in the villages where the children's bowels ran liquid they had fewer doctors now than before. Nobody counting the mothers after their time. Nobody counting much of anything.

In the cities they cut the babies out when they had to. Four in a hundred came that way. Out in the dusty provinces it was less. Two in a hundred. The numbers told a story of two countries living in one skin. City folk with their hospitals and their money. Village folk with their faith and their dead. The gap between rich and poor stretched twenty-seven percent wide, a canyon filled with the bones of the ones who couldn't pay.

The men in their offices talked about programs. Vertical approaches they called them, like ladders to heaven. Quick fixes and targeted goals. But he'd seen what happened when you poured money down one hole. The rest ran dry. AIDS got the dollars and the family clinics closed their doors. One program fought another, papers stacked on papers, forms in triplicate for bandages and pills. The whole system choking on its own blood.

He watched the sun set red over Jakarta. Somewhere in the provinces a woman was bleeding. Somewhere a child was dying of thirst. The numbers didn't matter anymore. Nothing mattered but the truth written in flesh and bone and the long dark night ahead.

The songs of man had grown like weeds in wasteland, sprouting and multiplying till no eye could count their number. A hundred years passed and still they grew, these sounds called Popular, branching like veins in the earth, each vein splitting again and again till the ground was shot through with their dark tendrils. Rap and rock and country and jazz and folk, mere stems from which countless others sprouted, twisted, multiplied.

But it was the sound they called Heavy Metal that grew wildest of all. Forty years it had been growing now, spreading like some nightblack fungus through the dreams of men. A sound that carried all the darkness of the human heart, though few would speak of such things. Those who made it saw how it could bend and twist and birth new forms, and so they bent it further still, each bending giving rise to stranger sounds until the very meaning of the thing was lost in shadow.

Now the sounds are numberless as stars. Metal has become a thing that devours all other sounds, consuming them and making them its own. To understand these sounds that echo through the concrete canyons of our cities you must first know the thing itself, this dark movement that is more than mere music.

It is a sound built on excess. More of everything - more thunder in the bass, more violence in the beat, more theater in the spectacle. The players are craftsmen of a sort, dark artisans who have mastered their tools through endless practice. And there are the drugs, always the drugs, flowing through the veins of the music like poison. In the seventies they came in waves, these chemical demons, twisting minds until the sounds that emerged were something altogether alien. The darkness that poured forth was new to ears accustomed to sweeter melodies. Some say you can hear echoes of the old Romantic composers in it, that same obsession with death and shadow and loss.

Take the Beatles song Helter Skelter, rising and falling like a fever dream. Some call it the first true Metal song, though others dispute this. The Beatles had heard the Stones growing darker, heavier, and would not be outdone. So they crafted their own darkness and sealed it in vinyl, never knowing what forces they had set loose upon the world.

He came to the painting like a man possessed by fever dreams. The Dream they called it. Nineteen and ten. The year meant nothing now. Rousseau had crafted it from the darkness in his mind, from places where no man ought venture but where artists cannot help but go. He was a man who knew nothing of art schools or fancy training, knew only the burning in his bones to make something true.

In them days before him the Surrealists hadnt yet come with their twisted visions and their nightmare shapes. But Rousseau he was already there, already walking them roads. The Dream showed a woman laid out like a corpse but breathing still, stretched on some velvet couch while around her the jungle grew wild and terrible. Strange flowers bloomed like drops of blood in the darkness. Lions with dead eyes watched from the shadows.

He'd been born in Laval. Some small town in France where his daddy worked metal and sold hardware to folks who needed such things. Grew up without knowing bout art except what lived in his heart. Worked forty years collecting tolls from travelers, watching their faces pass like ghosts through his booth. They called him douanier though that wasnt right. Gabelou was what he was. Words dont matter much now.

His first wife Clémence died after watching eight babies go into the ground. Left him with just the girl Julia and a emptiness that wouldnt fill. Maybe that's what drove him to the painting. Some men turn to drink but Rousseau he turned to colors and canvas like they was whiskey and wine.

He worked in them same days as Matisse and them other famous painters but he wasnt like them. Matisse painted cause he was scared of being common. Rousseau painted cause he wanted to be accepted by them that called themselves artists. Two men walking different roads to the same dark place. One running from something, one running to. Both of them lost in their own way.

Rousseau kept at it though. Kept putting brush to canvas like a man possessed. Like someone who knew the truth was in there somewhere if he just kept digging. If he just kept trying to speak what was in his heart even when nobody wanted to listen. Even when the world told him he was doing it all wrong.

He sat there thinking on the connection between what was right and what was beautiful, something them old philosophers had chewed on till their teeth wore down. Seemed to him there was truth in it. Like that poet Keats said about beauty and truth being the same thing. Most everything a man learns comes from books or from living but these things, they come different. Like they was already there waiting.

He remembered the Mona Lisa hanging in some museum somewhere, people standing round trying to explain why it was good. They'd talk about the background and the way the paint laid down and what it meant to them folks back then but that weren't really it. Truth was when somebody loved a painting or a book they'd always say there was just something about it before they got to talking smart. Something you couldn't put your finger on.

The same way with right and wrong he reckoned. Like that woman O'Connor said about stories, how sometimes you got to tell em cause there ain't no other way to say what needs saying. Don't matter how many words you use to describe a book, there's always something floating above em that you can't catch. Right and wrong was the same. That feller Wittgenstein knew it too. Said you couldn't really talk about ethics proper cause it was beyond talking about.

He figured that's what connected em, right and wrong and beautiful things. Both of em hit you somewhere deep down where words couldn't reach. Like seeing lightning far off in the dark. You could point to it but you couldn't never explain it right. Was strongest with books though. McKean had it figured. Said books was different from music and paintings cause they was full up with right and wrong same as life was. Couldn't live without deciding what was worth something and what weren't. That's why stories mattered. Cause they showed you what was worth keeping.

The land stretches out vast and ancient, from the shadow-wrapped peaks of München to the cold Baltic waters that lap at Kiel's shores. A country now but once it was something else. Something older. The culture runs deep like buried roots through the soil, from Köln where the Rhine cuts the earth to Dresden where the Elbe moves slow and dark past stone buildings that have seen too much. All of it connected yet separate, like bones in a skeleton that was pieced together from different graves.

Germania they called it. The old ones. The name itself is a ghost that scholars chase through time's corridors but never catch. Tacitus wrote of the Tungrians who became Germans when they crossed the Rhine with blood in their eyes and war in their hearts. Julius Caesar marked them in his writings, scratching their name into history with the same hand that had written victory after victory against the Gauls. He took their name from the Gauls' own tongue, using it to mark the difference between those he'd broken and those he hadn't. Some say the word meant neighbor in that old speech. Others claim it came from their spears, the ger that drank deep in battle, or from their war-cries that echoed through forests where Rome's eagles never flew.

Tacitus spoke of them as if they'd risen from the earth itself, pure as spring water and untouched by foreign blood. Who would come to such a place, he asked, with its wild darkness and its sky that wept cold tears? Only those born to it. Only those who called its forests home.

The Romans kept their distance mostly, sending their armies to gather what wealth they could find before retreating back to their marble columns and heated baths. But the tribes endured. They appeared like shadows in the first century, dwelling on the empire's edges, trading what the land gave them and sometimes their own blood, serving in legions far from their dark woods. The Romans might have conquered the world but here, in this place, the old ways persisted like tree roots that go too deep to dig out.

The play lay bare before him like some ancient text writ in the blood of false prophets. In it the truth of disguise and deception stretched out across the pages like a dead thing in the sun, useful perhaps in its time but ultimately destined to rot away leaving naught but bones. A man who takes up false cloth must someday shed it or lose himself to it forever. There aint no other way.

They was them that'd forgive such deception and them that wouldn't and there weren't no telling which was which till the truth come out raw and bleeding. The matter of taking up another's gender was worse still, like some dark covenant made with older gods than these. What sort of creature would cast off their own flesh for another's. What darkness dwelt in such souls.

Viola she had her reasons. Preservation pure and simple in a world gone wrong. I'll bring you to a captain in this town, she'd said, Where lie my maiden weeds, by whose gentle help I was preserved to serve this noble count. Words spoken like prayers in the night but prayers that'd damn her just the same. She took to wearing man's clothes like a second skin but it cut her off from the women folk, left her drifting in some terrible space between. Then Olivia, God help her, she went and fell in love with what weren't really there at all. Whither my lord, she called out. Cesario, husband, stay. Words that echoed in empty halls.

Orsino weren't no better. Boy thou hast said to me a thousand times thou never shouldst love woman like to me, he'd said, speaking truths he didn't know was truths. The whole thing laid bare something older than the clothes they wore or the flesh beneath. Something that lived in the dark spaces between what people said they wanted and what they truly desired deep in their bones.

Some might say Olivia's heart knew what her eyes couldn't see but that wasn't it at all. She was just another lost soul reaching out for whatever warmth she could find in a cold world. When she found Sebastian she turned from Cesario quick as summer lightning, calling out A sister you are she like them words could make the past unhappen. But the past don't unhappen. It just waits there in the dark, patient as stones.

They spoke of German rule in those lands with a darkness in their eyes. Tales of blood and bone scattered across the African plains where the Ovaherero and Nama had fallen. But empires aint built on simple stories and this one sprawled across the earth like some great dying beast, each limb moving to its own rhythm, its own terrible purpose.

In the east they found natives who could read and write, taught by German masters who believed in such things. The British came upon them in 1919 and marked their surprise at finding these educated souls. But in the southwest territories it was different. Different in the way a snake is different from a dove.

The southwest was a place of dust and heat where the missionaries did what schooling there was, the government offering little more than scraps from their table. But for the white children they built proper schools, good schools, laid down in neat rows like the headstones that would come later. The natives stayed in darkness, most of them, their minds untouched by letters or numbers, while across the other German lands their brothers learned to read by lamplight.

He'd seen maps of these places. Seen the names written in careful German script across lands they'd never truly known. Tanganyika. Kamerun. Names that echoed like bells in empty churches. The southwest had drawn the whites like moths to flame, fifteen thousand of them by 1913, more than anywhere else in their African realm. The climate wasnt so harsh there, though the desert stretched its dead fingers across much of the land.

They wrote books about it all, mostly in German at first, telling what they'd built and what they'd broken. Later came the English writers with their comparisons and their theories, trying to make sense of why some places bloomed while others withered. A man named Cohen wrote on it, said it was the settlers that made the difference, all those white faces turned toward Africa's sun. But there was more to it than that. There's always more to it than what gets wrote down in books.

The truth of it lay somewhere in the dust between what was and what might have been, in the space between the teachers and the taught, in the shadow lands where races met and parted like ships in the night, each bearing away their own version of the truth.

They were two nations once locked in blood and bile, the United States and Mexico, their hatred burning fifty-seven years through the darkness like some vengeful flame. The war came in 1846 and when it was done the victor had carved away Texas and the Southwest territories from the vanquished, leaving nothing but ash and bone and bitter memory. But there were other battles too, smaller wars fought in shadow and silence until the great war across the sea drew near.

The poison between them ran deep as a well. Religion stood between them like a wall of thorns, Catholic against Protestant, each claiming God's truth for their own. Their peoples looked across the divide and saw only strangers, inheritors of ancient hatreds carried across the sea from Spain and England like some dark cargo.

This was the way of nations that shared borders, their interests tangled like barbed wire. Through the years seventeen disputes bloomed like dark flowers, most born of the lawless frontier where bandits crossed back and forth leaving violence in their wake until both armies came to stand watch over the bloodstained earth.

The rivalry died slow, choking on its own bile as Mexico grew dependent on American coin and commerce. The conqueror's hunger changed from land to money, no longer seeking to devour territory but to feast on profit instead. The old hatred faded like morning mist but never truly vanished, lurking still in the shadows of memory where old wounds refuse to heal.

They were not so different from other rival nations sharing contested ground. Even now across the world such ancient feuds persist, fed by proximity and pride. The same story plays out again and again, written in blood across the pages of history. Only the names change while the darkness in men's hearts remains eternal.

Fifteen years back the sickness came. Not gradual like winter but sudden and complete, a thing I'd never heard tell of before though I was a nurse and knew the names of ailments like others know their kin.

I'd chose nursing cause it was safe and sure, something my childhood never was. They'd tell me time and again how folk would always need tending to, always be getting sick and needing care. So I buried my dreams of science and words deep down where they couldn't hurt none and took up the white uniform like a shield against the world's uncertainty.

Then there I was, forty-six years walked on this earth, alone with nothing saved and my body turned traitor. Still am to this day, living on government handouts like scraps thrown to dogs. Ain't got nothing I can rightfully call mine anymore. Each dawn brings its own battles against fear and shame, and nothing's certain except uncertainty itself. But there's one truth I learned hard - a body can't survive alone, no matter how strong they reckon themselves. When the darkness comes it strips you bare of all pretense.

Life's got its ambushes waiting. No amount of planning makes you bulletproof. Some storms are too big to weather alone, that's God's truth.

Folk talk about standing alone, being independent. But that ain't how the old ones made it. Wasn't no lone wolf survived the crossing west. It was communities bound together by something stronger than blood. Helping hands and shared bread, that's what built this land.

I keep my preparations, sure enough. Got my emergency supplies stacked like ammunition - water tablets, bandages, plastic sheeting and duct tape against the invisible enemies. Flashlights standing guard, batteries lined up like soldiers, candles and matches sealed against damp. Canned goods too, though they taste of tin and desperation.

But while you're laying in stores against the dark times coming, remember this - know your neighbors. Because when the real troubles come, it ain't your stockpile that'll save you. It's the hands reaching out in the darkness, the voices calling your name through the storm.

The prince who would become Buddha came into this world in the old days when men still believed in such things. Dark times those were and darker still would they become. He was born to wealth and privilege but saw through it like a man might see through glass darkened by time and the elements. The teachings he left behind grew into something called Buddhism and the most pure of these teachings they called Theravada. Twenty five hundred years have passed since then. Time changes all things. Even the things meant to remain unchanged.

In Sri Lanka where the old ways still hold sway they perform the water-cutting ceremony each year. Monks in their saffron robes and common folk alike gathering at the waters edge. Buddha never spoke of such things but men will make ceremonies where none existed before. The changes run deeper than mere ritual. They go down into the bones of the faith itself like roots seeking water in parched earth.

The changes came from within and without. Some bore the faith ill will and some meant it no harm but changed it all the same. Like a river that carries both clean water and poison downstream not caring which is which.

The heart of it was simple enough. Three things they held sacred: Buddha himself, his teachings they called Dhamma, and the brotherhood of monks they named Sangha. The teachings were kept in three vessels. The first held the words, the second held the rules for living, and the third held the deeper truths about the nature of things. They spoke of how nothing had a soul, how all life was suffering, how nothing lasted. A man could escape the wheel of death and rebirth if he understood these things truly. Could shed his desires and hatreds and delusions like a snake sheds its skin.

The rules were simple for common folk. Five things they must not do: take life, speak false, steal, lay with those they shouldnt, or cloud their minds with drink or worse. The monks had more rules. Many more. But at the center of it all lay four truths hard as stone: that life was suffering, that wanting things caused suffering, that a man could escape suffering if he knew how. These were the foundations everything else was built upon. Like the footings of an ancient wall that still stood while all around it had fallen to ruin.

original_texts:
Culture plays a significant role in any negotiation. Culture can be defined as much by what it is not as what it actually is and what it signifies. Culture is not homogenous, nor is it a specific thing. It is also not singular or uniform. Statements such as “all Russians are stubborn” or “all Japanese are accommodating,” are inherently broad and overly simplistic. While the understanding of a culture’s generalizations are appropriate, it is much more productive to a negotiator to understand the significance of a culture to the matter at hand, and how that culture’s attitude can and will affect the table talks. When one approaches a foreign culture, one experiences it in a way that is relatable to his own culture, and comparisons necessarily arise. 

Attempting to understand a foreign culture or mindset can involve anything from studying its history to realizing its prejudices. Rather than judging or attempting to change a culture, one must simply accept it for what it is, and work within its boundaries, especially within the scope of negotiation, and most especially if one comes to the table with a weaker bargaining position. Likewise, if a negotiator finds himself on “away” territory, a respect for traditions and beliefs can only help in getting over any cultural barriers and move the negotiation forward.

It is important to note that culture does not necessarily limit itself to a national/international dichotomy. Most companies within a given nation establish their own corporate culture. For instance, a corporate culture might emphasize long hours in the office or a more relaxed schedule. Evidence of a corporate culture can be seen in employee dress codes, in communication style (direct v. indirect communication, delegation of duties), and hiring practices. Some companies encourage philanthropy at any level from employees, others restrict it to “company approved” charities or fundraisers. One need only look at the differences in American corporate culture from company to company (and indeed, intra-company diversity exists even from region to region, urban to suburban environments included) to appreciate the diversity of thought that can reside within a particular societal culture. Certain cultures are not nearly as stratified as American culture, and may appear more uniform to an outsider, but a similar exterior is simply a sign to dig deeper. 

Values are even more important to understand, because they provide the why of a culture. If saving face or communal harmony are valued within a culture, it is certain that a negotiator will not publicly shame his company or his superior in order to succeed at the negotiation table. Likewise, a negotiator from a culture which gives greater weight to a hard-driven bargain will not necessarily be driven to settle at the earliest opportunity. Taking these generalities into consideration is important before one gets to the negotiating table. However, a negotiator is well-served to learn something about his opponent on a personal level in order to make the negotiation effective.

“The fool hath said in his heart, ‘There is no God.’” The preceding quotation is seen first in Psalm 14 of the Christian Bible, and is found at the beginning of St. Anselm’s argument regarding the existence of God. This belief seems to also be held by the other author whom we will be discussing, Thomas Aquinas. Because each of their arguments is in defense of the same concept, and our challenge is to determine who’s is the better of the two, we must, for sake of brevity, begin with the presumption that they are both correct in their belief in the existence of God, specifically the God of the Bible. To allow for a God-type figure that may not resemble the one in whom our two authors believe would not permit us to appropriately compare their two arguments, as they are essentially in defense of one specific concept of God. That being said, I would suggest that while each of them brings up valid points, neither truly provides a holistic basis for belief in God.
	To illustrate this point, we will first examine the basic argument of St. Anselm. Anselm’s passage reflects a path of gaining understanding through faith, looking within one’s self to find proof of God. He explains that because God exists within our understanding, we cannot effectively conceive his nonexistence. While this concept, when spelled out in his terminology, is a bit tedious and at times unclear, the basic gist of it is that the proof for God lies within one’s own mind. St. Anselm is suggesting to us that we needn’t go beyond the confines of our own soul to find truth about God, but that the existence of this being is found to be true simply by examining that which we inherently know to be true within our own minds. Foreign evidence is presumably unnecessary. This concept of accepting that for which there is not an irrefutable body of empirical evidence is often referred to within Christian texts as faith.
	This idea is very different from that held by St. Thomas Aquinas. Aquinas instead suggests that the existence of God can be proven entirely through reason and empirical evidence, with no need for faith of any kind. Such an idea would be beneficial in evangelism, an important element of Christianity, because it would enable the recruiting of new converts without any dependency upon their willingness to accept something that cannot be proven. They could instead be persuaded by logic alone. St. Thomas elaborates on five different logical arguments supporting the existence of God: change, causation, contingency, degrees of excellence, and harmony. In each he essentially demonstrates that the proof of God lies in the logical necessity for God. If you are told that that you are missing one puzzle piece, and assemble the rest of the puzzle, logic dictates that you can know of the features and the existence of the missing piece without having to see it.

Many authors use different ways to give their readers a certain feeling or attitude toward
important subjects. Some of these techniques are more effective than others. F. Scott Fitzgerald uses
many of these different techniques in his novel The Great Gatsby. Sometimes, Fitzgerald pairs an
adjective and a noun together that do not usually fit that way to give readers a certain aura around a
subject. Other times, he applies meaning to a symbol, and then uses it for this same purpose.
Fitzgerald uses this last technique with many colors, including gold, green, white/gray and red/pink. In
his novel The Great Gatsby F. Scott Fitzgerald builds up meaning for colors, namely white/gray and
red/pink then later uses that meaning to give readers a certain reminder of a feeling around an
important object.
The meaning Fitzgerald builds up and uses for white/gray is uniformity, with white being a bit
nicer and higher class and gray being more older and faded. Fitzgerald sets up this meaning in the
beginning of the novel with constant uses of both. Daisy and Jordan are constantly “in white” (8)—in
fact, everyone is always wearing white: Nick wears “white flannels” (41) to Gatsby’s party, Tom wears
a “white shirt” (36) when he meets Myrtle, and Catherine is “powdered milky white” (30). In fact, the
only time people are not wearing white is when Nick is getting his impressions of Gatsby’s party: “the
halls... are gaudy with primary colors” (40). Fitzgerald further defines these two colors in coloring
many common, unimportant subjects these colors: as Nick goes to work, he goes “down the white
chasms of lower New York” (56), the names of people at Gatsby’s parties are now “gray names” (61)
on Nick’s timetable, Catherine’s apartment is “one slice in a long white cake of apartment-houses”—
uniformity (28). He also describes plain or common people or places as white or gray: Jordan and
Daisy had a “white girlhood” (19) together, there are “gray cars” and “gray land” (23) in the valley of
ashes, the “Italian child” in the railroad is “gray” (26), and the dog-seller is “a gray old man” (27).
After Fitzgerald adds enough meaning to white/gray, he uses them to signify unimportance or
uniformity to certain subjects. This using colors to show readers something first starts with Daisy.
After a long time without any significant use of either of these colors, Fitzgerald comes out describing
Daisy as “dressed in white” in “a little white roadster”; readers begin to see Daisy as less of a character,
more like just a uniform addition, something that Gatsby wants and longs for (74). Fitzgerald uses
more of this technique around Daisy to give this impression of Daisy being a more uniform addition,
for example, there is a “gray haze of Daisy’s fur collar” (18), and she is again in a “white” (115) dress
before Tom and Gatsby’s encounter.

San Diego County is very agriculturally productive, thanks to a mild, sunny climate. Common crops include: tomatoes, citrus, leafy greens, squash, broccoli, herbs, tree fruits like peaches and lemons, berries, honey, and peppers. There is a substantial market for organic community supported agriculture food in the San Diego area, with many local organizations having lengthy waiting lists. Organic eggs and milk are also popular. Many organic farms also provide tours of their agricultural operations as well as access for hiking, birdwatching, and other recreational activities. This is the type of operation that would allow the landowner to gain the benefits of government programs while improving habitat, thus allowing recreational use and creating an opportunity for farm tours and other programs for making money or for educational purposes.  
	In addition to filling a potentially lucrative niche market, the benefits of organic farming often include greater biodiversity in plants and wildlife in the area thanks to a lack of chemicals in the soil and water. However, organic farming has greater costs than conventional farming in some ways. It requires more intensive labor and management to remove pests and weeds and fertilize the soil without chemicals, and losses are often greater than with conventional methods, while a small organic farm also lacks the efficiency of scale of large operations. Practices not related to organic farming but beneficial to wildlife may also incur greater labor costs, including planting cover crops, strategic grazing rotation, invasive species removal, and active management of plant growth to provide specific conditions such as edge habitat or patches of open ground. Thus, there are many reasons why the landowner in this example might seek financial help or expertise in maximizing both profits and habitat quality.  
The land chosen for this scenario is a parcel adjacent to the town of Potrero, in unincorporated San Diego County, California. It is 160 acres of chaparral, nonnative Mediterranean grassland, and oak woodland next to to the Cleveland National Forest. It lies in the East County Southern Foothills ecoregion of the San Diego Multiple Species Conservation Plan. The plan is still being reviewed, but presently considers over a hundred species of plants and animals. Many are endangered, such as the Stephens' kangaroo rat, the mountain yellow-legged frog, several species of butterfly, and the California gnatcatcher; others are declining and may soon be listed, such as burrowing owls.
	This area was inhabited by Native Americans for untold centuries and was then settled by cattle ranchers and cordwood sellers in the late 1800's. This piece of land was part of an original homestead patent and so was probably used for grazing and/or wood production for many of the intervening decades.
